sentences.sentence: It was so sudden, and so horribly unlike anything that had ever happened to Digory even in a nightmare( 噩梦 ), that he let out a scream.
Instantly Uncle Andrew’s hand was over his mouth.
“None of that!” he hissed( 低声呵斥 ) in Digory’s ear. “If you start making a noise your Mother’ll hear it.
And you know what a fright might do to her.”
As Digory said afterward( 之后 ), the horrible( 恐怖的 ) meanness of getting at a chap( 小伙子 ) in that way, almost made him sick.
But of course he didn’t scream again.
“That’s better,” said Uncle Andrew. “Perhaps you couldn’t help it.
It is a shock when you first see someone vanish( 消失 ).
Why, it gave even me a turn when the guinea-pig( 豚鼠 ) did it the other night.”
“Was that when you yelled( 喊叫 )?” asked Digory.
“Oh, you heard that, did you? I hope you haven’t been spying( 监视 ) on me?”
“No, I haven’t,” said Digory indignantly( 气愤地 ). “But what’s happened to Polly?”
“Congratulate me, my dear boy,” said Uncle Andrew, rubbing( 搓 ) his hands. “My experiment has succeeded.
The little girl’s gone—vanished( 消失 )—right out of the world.”
“What have you done to her?”
“Sent her to—well—another place.”
“What do you mean?” asked Digory.
Uncle Andrew sat down and said, “Well, I’ll tell you all about it. Have you ever heard of old Mrs. Lefay?”
“Wasn’t she a great-aunt or something?” said Digory.
“Not exactly,” said Uncle Andrew. “She was my godmother( 教母 ). That’s her, there, on the wall.”
Digory looked and saw a faded( 褪色的 ) photograph: it showed the face of an old woman in a bonnet( 女士软帽 ).
And he could now remember that he had once seen a photo of the same face in an old drawer, at home, in the country.
He had asked his Mother who it was and Mother had not seemed to want to talk about the subject much.
It was not at all a nice face, Digory thought, though of course with those early photographs one could never really tell.
“Was there—wasn’t there—something wrong about her, Uncle Andrew?” he asked.
“Well,” said Uncle Andrew with a chuckle( 低声轻笑 ), “it depends what you call wrong. People are so narrow-minded.
She certainly got very queer( 奇怪的 ) in later life. Did very unwise things. That was why they shut her up.”
“In an asylum( 精神病院 ), do you mean?
“Oh no, no, no,” said Uncle Andrew in a shocked voice. “Nothing of that sort. Only in prison.”
“I say!” said Digory. “What had she done?”
“Ah, poor woman,” said Uncle Andrew. “She had been very unwise.
There were a good many different things.
We needn’t go into all that. She was always very kind to me.”
“But look here, what has all this got to do with Polly? I do wish you’d—”
“All in good time, my boy,” said Uncle Andrew.
“They let old Mrs. Lefay out before she died and I was one of the very few people whom she would allow to see her in her last illness.
She had got to dislike ordinary, ignorant( 无知的 ) people, you understand. I do myself.
But she and I were interested in the same sort of things.
It was only a few days before her death that she told me to go to an old bureau( 书桌 ) in her house and open a secret drawer and bring her a little box that I would find there.
The moment I picked up that box I could tell by the pricking( 刺痛感 ) in my fingers that I held some great secret in my hands.
She gave it me and made me promise that as soon as she was dead I would burn it, unopened, with certain ceremonies.
That promise I did not keep.”
“Well, then, it was jolly( 非常地 ) rotten( 糟糕的 ) of you,” said Digory.
“Rotten( 糟糕的 )?” said Uncle Andrew with a puzzled( 困惑的 ) look. “Oh, I see. You mean that little boys ought to keep their promises.
Very true: most right and proper, I’m sure, and I’m very glad you have been taught to do it.
But of course you must understand that rules of that sort, however excellent they may be for little boys—and servants—and women—and even people in general,
can’t possibly be expected to apply to profound( 知识渊博的 ) students and great thinkers and sages( 圣人 ).
No, Digory. Men like me, who possess hidden wisdom, are freed from common rules just as we are cut off from common pleasures.
Ours, my boy, is a high and lonely destiny( 命运 ).”
As he said this he sighed and looked so grave( 严肃的 ) and noble and mysterious( 神秘的 ) that for a second Digory really thought he was saying something rather fine.
But then he remembered the ugly look he had seen on his Uncle’s face the moment before Polly had vanished( 消失 ): and all at once( 突然 ) he saw through Uncle Andrew’s grand words.
“All it means,” he said to himself, “is that he thinks he can do anything he likes to get anything he wants.”
“Of course,” said Uncle Andrew, “I didn’t dare to open the box for a long time, for I knew it might contain something highly dangerous.
For my godmother( 教母 ) was a very remarkable woman.
The truth is, she was one of the last mortals( 凡人 ) in this country who had fairy( 仙子 ) blood( 血统 ) in her.
(She said there had been two others in her time. One was a duchess( 公爵夫人 ) and the other was a charwoman( 女清洁工 ).)
In fact, Digory, you are now talking to the last man (possibly) who really had a fairy( 仙子 ) godmother( 教母 ).
There! That’ll be something for you to remember when you are an old man yourself.”
“I bet( 打赌 ) she was a bad fairy( 仙子 ),” thought Digory; and added out loud. “But what about Polly?”
“How you do harp on( 喋喋不休 ) that!” said Uncle Andrew. “As if that was what mattered!
My first task was of course to study the box itself. It was very ancient.
And I knew enough even then to know that it wasn’t Greek, or Old Egyptian, or Babylonian( 巴比伦的 ), or Hittite( 希泰族的 ), or Chinese.
It was older than any of those nations.
Ah—that was a great day when I at last found out the truth.
The box was Atlantean( 亚特兰蒂斯的 ); it came from the lost island of Atlantis( 亚特兰蒂斯 ).
That meant it was centuries older than any of the stone-age things they dig up( 挖掘 ) in Europe.
And it wasn’t a rough, crude( 粗制的 ) thing like them either.
For in the very dawn( 开始 ) of time Atlantis( 亚特兰蒂斯 ) was already a great city with palaces and temples and learned men.”
He paused for a moment as if he expected Digory to say something.
But Digory was disliking his Uncle more every minute, so he said nothing.
“Meanwhile,” continued Uncle Andrew, “I was learning a good deal in other ways (it wouldn’t be proper to explain them to a child) about Magic in general.
That meant that I came to have a fair idea what sort of things might be in the box.
By various tests I narrowed down( 缩小 ) the possibilities.
I had to get to know some—well, some devilish( 非常 ) queer( 奇怪的 ) people, and go through some very disagreeable experiences.
That was what turned my head gray.
One doesn’t become a magician for nothing.
My health broke down in the end. But I got better. And at last I actually knew.”
Although there was not really the least chance of anyone overhearing( 偷听 ) them, he leaned( 倾斜 ) forward and almost whispered as he said:
“The Atlantean( 亚特兰蒂斯的 ) box contained something that had been brought from another world when our world was only just beginning.”
“What?” asked Digory, who was now interested in spite of himself.
“Only dust,” said Uncle Andrew. “Fine, dry dust. Nothing much to look at.
Not much to show for a lifetime of toil( 辛苦劳作 ), you might say.
Ah, but when I looked at that dust (I took jolly( 非常地 ) good care not to touch it) and thought that every grain had once been in another world—I don’t mean another planet, you know;

they’re part of our world and you could get to them if you went far enough—but a really Other World—another Nature—another universe—somewhere you would never reach even if you traveled through the space of this universe forever and ever—a world that could be reached only by Magic—well!”
Here Uncle Andrew rubbed( 搓 ) his hands till his knuckles( 指关节 ) cracked( 噼啪作响 ) like fireworks( 爆竹 ).
“I knew,” he went on, “that if only you could get it into the right form, that dust would draw you back to the place it had come from.
But the difficulty was to get it into the right form.
My earlier experiments were all failures.
I tried them on guinea-pigs( 豚鼠 ). Some of them only died.
Some exploded( 爆炸 ) like little bombs—”
“It was a jolly( 非常地 ) cruel thing to do,” said Digory who had once had a guinea-pig( 豚鼠 ) of his own.
“How you do keep getting off the point!” said Uncle Andrew.
“That’s what the creatures were for. I’d bought them myself. Let me see—where was I?
Ah yes. At last I succeeded in making the rings: the yellow rings.
But now a new difficulty arose.
I was pretty sure, now, that a yellow ring would send any creature that touched it into the Other Place.
But what would be the good of that if I couldn’t get them back to tell me what they had found there?”
“And what about them?” said Digory. “A nice mess they’d be in if they couldn’t get back!”
“You will keep on looking at everything from the wrong point of view,” said Uncle Andrew with a look of impatience( 不耐心 ).
“Can’t you understand that the thing is a great experiment?
The whole point of sending anyone into the Other Place is that I want to find out what it’s like.”
“Well why didn’t you go yourself then?”

article_info.previous: 空屋的小阁楼上到底藏着什么秘密？Polly和Digory怀着好奇心进行了一场探险，但是出现在小阁楼里的Uncle Andrew，几枚黄色和绿色的戒指，突然消失的Polly，Uncle Andrew到底隐藏着多少不可告人的秘密呢？

article_info.share_words: It was so sudden, and so horribly unlike anything that had ever happened to Digory even in a nightmare, that he let out a scream.

question.en: According to Uncle Andrew, who was Mrs. Lefay?

analysis: 文中当Digory询问道：“Wasn’t she a great-aunt or something?”Uncle Andrew说道：“Not exactly. . . she was my godmother.”因此可以得知Mr. Lefay是Uncle Andrew的教母，因此选C。

question.cn: 根据Uncle Andrew的叙述，Mrs.Lefay为什么会被关起来？
question.en: According to Uncle Andrew, why did people shut Mrs. Lefay up?

options.cn: 因为她很奇怪，并且做了不明智的事。
options.en: Because she was weird and did unwise things.
Because she tried to commit suicide.

analysis: 文中提到：“She certainly got very queer later in life. Did very unwise things. That was why they shut her up.”因此答案选B.

question.cn: 在Mrs. Lefay弥留之际，她送给了Uncle Andrew什么东西？
question.en: What did Mrs. Lefay give Uncle Andrew while she lay dying?

analysis: 文中提到：“It was only a few days before her death that she told me to go to an old bureau in her house. . . and bring her a little box that I would find there.”可知Mrs. Lefay在临死的时候送给Uncle Andrew一个盒子，因此答案选B。

question.cn: Mrs. Lefay送给Uncle Andrew的盒子里装的是什么？
question.en: What was in the box given by Mrs. Lefay?

analysis: 当Digory问盒子里装的是什么时，文中提到：“‘Only dust,’ said Uncle Andrew. ‘Fine, dry dust. Nothing much to look at.’”因此本题选A。
